Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Propofol in Pediatric Anesthesia

Background: This study aimed to evaluate the impact of propofol on pediatric anesthesia pharmacology and its role in infusion pump development for maintenance anesthesia.

Methods: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with participants recruited from pediatric anesthesia settings. Eligibility criteria included children requiring anesthesia for surgical procedures. Participants were randomly assigned to receive either propofol or a comparator anesthetic. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Intervention: The intervention group received propofol, while the control group received an alternative anesthetic. The primary outcome was the depth of anesthesia, measured using EEG signals over a 24-hour period.

Results: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group. Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach. The mean difference in depth of anesthesia was 5.2 units (95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01). Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Interpretation: Propofol significantly improved the depth of anesthesia compared to the control, with a favorable safety profile. The study supports the use of propofol in pediatric anesthesia and highlights its role in advancing infusion pump technology.

Trial registration: NCT12345678

Funding: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
